item.title: Saudis Say Airstrike in Yemen Targeted Arms From U.A.E.
item.description: The Saudi-led coalition said its strike, at a port in southern Yemen, targeted weapons bound for a separatist group backed by the United Arab Emirates.
item.dc:creator: Saeed Al-Batati and Ismaeel Naar

media:content.media:description: Soldiers loyal to the Southern Transitional Council, a separatist group backed by the United Arab Emirates, in Aden, Yemen, early this month.

item.title: With Live Artillery and New Warships, China Practices Blockading Taiwan
item.description: China flew bombers and fired long-range artillery during a second day of exercises designed to show its ability to claim the island-democracy by force.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien

media:content.media:description: The Chinese military fired a rocket on Tuesday from Pingtan, an island in the eastern province of Fujian that is China’s closest point to Taiwan.

item.title: Una expedición científica para estudiar el ‘Glaciar del Juicio Final’
item.description: Nuestros periodistas enviarán despachos periódicos mientras se dirigen a la Antártida acompañando a científicos que intentan calibrar los peligros del calentamiento del mar.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong and Mira Rojanasakul

media:content.media:credit: Ian Strachan/EYOS Expeditions, vía Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Un iceberg colosal en los mares de la Antártida en 2024.

item.title: Palestinian Artists on Two Years of War in Gaza
item.description: Times Opinion asked eight working Palestinian artists about the role of art in the war in Gaza.

item.title: In Lagos, December Is Time to Get Down and ‘Detty’
item.description: Detty December means a month of “back to back to back” partying in Nigeria’s megacity, both for locals and visiting members of the diaspora. Bring your stamina, dancing shoes and wads of cash.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean and Taiwo Aina

media:content.media:credit: Taiwo Aina for The New York Times

item.title: Yonaguni, the Japanese Island on the Front Lines of China’s Feud with Japan
item.description: Yonaguni, a tiny Japanese island near Taiwan, is getting soldiers, radar and missiles. As China’s dispute with Tokyo escalates, some residents are worried.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández, Hisako Ueno and Ko Sasaki

media:content.media:description: Yonaguni, a Japanese military outpost about 70 miles east of Taiwan, sits along the so-called “first island chain,” a strategic arc of islands used to hem in Chinese naval expansion.

item.title: Corrections: Dec. 30, 2025
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Dec. 30, 2025.

item.title: Quote of the Day: Green Marvel or Ghost City? Deciding the Fate of Nusantara.
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, December 30, 2025.

item.title: C.I.A. Conducted Drone Strike on Port in Venezuela
item.description: The attack last week, on a dock purportedly used for shipping narcotics, did not kill anyone, people briefed on the operation said. But it was the first known U.S. operation inside Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Tyler Pager

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Speaking to reporters on Monday, President Trump had declined to say how the attack had been carried out or by whom but confirmed the United States was responsible.

item.title: Justice Department Sues Virginia Over Tuition Aid for Unauthorized Immigrants
item.description: The department said the state’s policy of granting unauthorized immigrants in-state financial aid at public colleges and universities violates federal law.
item.dc:creator: Tim Balk

media:content.media:credit: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The University of Virginia campus in Charlottesville, Va.

item.title: In One Year, Trump’s War on Immigration Alters the Face of America
item.description: The crackdown and detentions swept from one coast to the other: day laborers in Los Angeles, a flower seller in Chicago, immigrants in New York courtrooms.

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers for Dec. 30, 2025
item.description: Geoffrey Schorkopf and Will Eisenberg have their first crossword collaboration in The New York Times.
item.dc:creator: Sam Corbin

item.title: Year 1 of Trump’s Immigration Crackdown: ICE Raids, Deportations and Protests
item.description: The crackdown and detentions swept from one coast to the other: day laborers in Los Angeles, a flower seller in Chicago, immigrants in New York courtrooms.
item.dc:creator: Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Photographs By Todd Heisler
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Why This Glacier Worries Scientists the Most
item.description: Our climate reporter Raymond Zhong describes how the fast-melting Thwaites Glacier of Antarctica, is like a cork in a bottle: If it starts to really disintegrate, many more glaciers around it could do the same, with major consequences for sea levels.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong, Kassie Bracken, Christina Thornell, Jon Miller, Stephanie Swart, Leila Medina, Phil Caller and Nikolay Nikolov

item.title: Khaleda Zia, Bangladesh’s First Female Prime Minister, Dies
item.description: A leader for three terms, she traded the country’s leadership with Sheikh Hasina, the head of another political dynasty, over decades. She was believed to be 80.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat and Mujib Mashal
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

media:content.media:credit: Khaled Hasan for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Khaleda Zia in 2014.

item.title: An Anti-A.I. Movement Is Coming. Which Party Will Lead It?
item.description: The technology Is ruining much of what makes life worth living.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg

item.title: U.S. Kills 2 in Strike in Pacific, as Trump Pressures Venezuela
item.description: The attack was the 30th announced by the U.S. military since early September. It came days after President Trump said the U.S. had struck a coastal site related to drugs and Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The strike, conducted at the direction of Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, had targeted a boat sailing along a “known narco-trafficking route” in the eastern Pacific.

item.title: Hundreds Sue Virginia Hospital and Executives Over Unneeded Surgeries
item.description: More than 500 women claimed that they had received unnecessary operations. Hospital leaders said they were not aware of a doctor’s misconduct.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin

media:content.media:credit: Western Tidewater Regional Jail, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Javaid Perwaiz is serving a 59-year prison sentence after being convicted of health care fraud arising from medically unnecessary surgeries at Chesapeake Regional Medical Center in Chesapeake, Va.

item.title: Trump and Netanyahu Praise Each Other After Meeting, Despite Differences Over Gaza
item.description: The American and Israeli leaders showed few signs of disagreement after meeting in Florida, giving no public indication of their growing strains over Gaza, Syria and other issues.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager and David M. Halbfinger

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times

item.title: Democrats Aim to Spotlight Republican Efforts to Rewrite the Jan. 6 Capitol Riot
item.description: On the fifth anniversary of the attack, which falls next Tuesday, Democrats plan to hold an informal hearing to review President Trump’s clemency for the rioters and G.O.P. attempts to sanitize the event.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack

media:content.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Trump supporters heading toward the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. The ensuing riot caused millions of dollars in damage, injured more than 140 police officers and interrupted the certification of the presidential election.

item.title: New York City Takes Over Maimonides Hospital in Brooklyn
item.description: Maimonides Health is a community fixture that will become part of NYC Health + Hospitals. Many of its patients are on government medical plans.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack

media:content.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Maimonides Health operates three hospitals and more than 80 other sites in Brooklyn.

item.title: Trump and Netanyahu Present United Front During Meeting
item.description: President Trump and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel lavished each other with praise during their meeting on Monday. The two discussed Gaza’s reconstruction. Mr. Netanyahu also gave Mr. Trump the Israel Prize, the country’s highest cultural honor.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Leventhal

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times

item.title: Russia Threatens to Harden Its Stance on Ukraine
item.description: Plus, food trends for 2026. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
item.dc:creator: Whet Moser

media:content.media:description: A Ukrainian antiaircraft defense unit in the Donetsk region last week.

item.title: Idris Elba and Cynthia Erivo Make King Charles’s New Year Honors List
item.description: Mr. Elba received a knighthood and Ms. Erivo was also honored in an annual British tradition celebrating professional excellence and community service.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom

media:content.media:description: England’s national women’s team lifts the trophy after defeating Spain to win the European women’s soccer championship, in July in Switzerland.

item.title: New Year’s Eve Concerts at Kennedy Center Are Canceled
item.description: The jazz drummer Billy Hart said the decision was “evidently” connected to President Trump’s name being added to the arts center.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney and Neil Vigdor
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts

media:content.media:description: The head of Doug Varone and Dancers called the decision to cancel two performances at the Kennedy Center “financially devastating but morally exhilarating.”

item.title: Gone in 2025: A Yearlong Procession of Giants
item.description: Marquee names all, they found international fame in the arts, politics, the sciences and beyond.
item.dc:creator: William McDonald

media:content.media:credit: Photo Illustration by Leslie dela Vega/The New York Times; Photos: Emma McIntyre/Getty Images for TCM; George Brich, via Associated Press; Michael Tighe, via Donaldson Collection, via Getty Images; Amy Sussman, via Getty Images; Remo Csilli, via Reuters; Henning Kaiser, via DDP, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images; Ron Galella Collection, via Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Clockwise from left: Rob Reiner, Val Kilmer, Diane Keaton, David Lynch, Robert Redford, Pope Francis and Gene Hackman.

item.title: Notable Deaths of 2025
item.description: As the year winds to a close, we’re recalling those we’ve lost who forged consequential lives.

item.title: Louis V. Gerstner, Who Revived a Faltering IBM in the ’90s, Dies at 83
item.description: Installed as an outsider, he engineered a comeback, shifting the company’s focus from a waning mainframe computer business toward consulting and services.
item.dc:creator: Steve Lohr

media:content.media:credit: Richard L. Harbus for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Louis V. Gerstner Jr. in his office at IBM’s headquarters in Armonk, N.Y., in 2001. He was with Dr. Yvette Burton, a technology consultant.

item.title: Goodbye to Brigitte Bardot’s Cruel Charm
item.description: In Brigitte Bardot’s death I see the passing of a generation: the Frenchwomen who tried to find a path to autonomy in the 1950s and ’60s.
item.dc:creator: Nadja Spiegelman

item.title: Israel Strips U.N. Agency for Palestinian Refugees of Diplomatic Immunity
item.description: The legislation was the latest blow to the agency, known as UNRWA. Israel has accused it of being extensively infiltrated by Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Johnatan Reiss
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency

media:content.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Flour being distributed in Gaza City from a center run by UNRWA, in April.

item.title: Cambia tu dirección de Gmail sin perder información
item.description: Los usuarios se sentían atrapados ante la imposibilidad de realizar el cambio sin perder todos los datos y servicios asociados.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan

media:content.media:description: Google ha empezado a desplegar discretamente una forma de que los usuarios cambien sus direcciones de Gmail que terminan en @gmail.com, y conserven todos sus correos electrónicos.

item.title: Mamdani Will Be Sworn In at Abandoned Subway Station Beneath City Hall
item.description: Hours before Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani holds an inauguration block party outside City Hall, he will officially become mayor in a small private ceremony.
item.dc:creator: Jeffery C. Mays

media:content.media:description: The old City Hall Station, which has been out of commission since 1945, is famous for its arches.

item.title: The Year in Pictures
item.description: We look back on 2025 with some of the best New York Times photographs.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold

item.title: What We’re Bringing to Antarctica
item.description: What do a New York Times reporter and photographer pack for a two-month expedition to the fastest-melting glacier in Antarctica? Raymond Zhong and Chang W. Lee compare the must-have gear that they’re bringing for the journey.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong, Chang W. Lee, Claire Hogan, Christina Thornell, Kassie Bracken, Jon Miller and Leila Medina

item.title: El mar arrastra a Colombia pruebas de los ataques aéreos de Trump
item.description: Primero fue la embarcación calcinada. Luego los cuerpos destrozados y los paquetes con restos de marihuana. Ahora, los pescadores temen zarpar al océano que los alimenta.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak, Simón Posada, Christiaan Triebert and Federico Rios
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )

item.title: Romney’s Pitch to Tax the Rich Is ‘Not Punishment’
item.description: Readers react to Mitt Romney’s call to raise taxes on the wealthy. Also: the moral bankruptcy revealed by the Epstein files.

item.title: U.S. Pledges $2 Billion for U.N. Aid but Trump Administration Tells Agencies to ‘Adapt, Shrink, or Die’
item.description: The announcement will likely keep the United States as the biggest international aid donor next year, even as the Trump administration slashes funding for foreign assistance programs.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.category: United States Agency for International Development

media:content.media:description: Bags of rations being unloaded at a World Food Program distribution point last year at a temporary camp for refugees from Sudan in Adre, Chad.

item.title: Trump, Pressing Ahead on Ukraine-Russia Talks, Confronts Difficult Realities
item.description: The U.S.-led negotiations have made some progress, but still face fundamental challenges, including over security guarantees to counter future Russian aggression.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger

media:content.media:description: Soldiers with a Ukrainian antiaircraft defense unit monitoring the sky for Russian drones in the Donetsk region last week.

item.title: How a Research Trip to Antarctica Deals With Time Zones
item.description: The clocks aboard our icebreaker will be changed several times en route to Antarctica. It’s one of many things that make the expedition feel otherworldly.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong

media:content.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Russia Threatens to Toughen Its Stance on Ending the War in Ukraine
item.description: Moscow said a Ukrainian drone attack targeted a residence of President Vladimir V. Putin, which Ukraine denied, accusing the Kremlin of fabricating an excuse not to make peace.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar and Ivan Nechepurenko

media:content.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia meeting with military officers in Moscow on Monday, in a photo released by Russian state media.

item.title: When the Best New Year’s Plans Are No New Year’s Plans
item.description: Many opt out of the revelry, either as their own time-honored tradition or because of a different outlook this year.
item.dc:creator: Alyson Krueger

media:content.media:credit: Lexey Swall for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: For some, home is where the party is.

item.description: Hokkaido scallops, harvested from cold, nutrient-rich waters, are prized for their buttery umami and command premium prices in China’s high-end banquet culture.

item.description: Yonaguni, a tiny Japanese island near Taiwan, is getting soldiers, radar and missiles.

item.title: Brigitte Bardot: su vida en fotos
item.description: El cine convirtió a la actriz francesa en una estrella, pero la fotografía cimentó su estatus de icono.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

item.title: Grim Evidence of Trump’s Boat Strikes Washes Ashore on a Colombian Peninsula
item.description: First came the scorched boat. Then the mangled bodies. Then the packets with traces of marijuana. Now, fishermen fear the ocean that feeds them.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak, Simón Posada, Christiaan Triebert and Federico Rios

item.title: Melanie Watson Bernhardt, ‘Diff’rent Strokes’ Actress, Dies at 57
item.description: Her four episodes on the sitcom marked a rarity: a disabled actress onscreen.
item.dc:creator: Sopan Deb

media:content.media:description: Melanie Watson Bernhardt played Kathy Gordon in the hit television show “Diff’rent Strokes” starring Gary Coleman.

item.title: Video Captures Aftermath of U.S. Airstrike on Boat Off Venezuela
item.description: A resident on the Guajira Peninsula in Colombia captured a large plume of black smoke rising from the Gulf of Venezuela. The video, in which a ringtone plays in the background, is the only known independent footage of the aftermath of U.S. military strikes on boats the Trump administration says are smuggling drugs.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Police Raid on Suspected ISIS Safe House in Turkey Turns Deadly
item.description: Three police officers and six militants were killed in clashes during a police raid on a suspected Islamic State safe house in Turkey on Monday, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Monika Cvorak
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

media:content.media:description: A raid on a suspected Islamic State safe house in northwestern Turkey on Monday left nine people dead.

item.title: Try Our Quiz on Literary Romantic Adventures
item.description: Need something to read (or watch) this New Year’s week? This quiz brings the love.
item.dc:creator: J. D. Biersdorfer

item.title: Journey to the Melting Continent
item.description: The New York Times is joining an expedition by sea to Antarctica’s fastest-thinning glaciers.
